content: Thanks for the response, Jesse. I would really recommend you at least read the linked Alfie Kohn article. I think you’ll see that the research is pretty clear: grades don’t help us “advance.” And I personally don’t like preparing kids to “cope” with the educational malpractice they may experience later. Nor am I recommending a new fad, as the research on these ideas is now decades and decades old. Grades are a relatively recent development in the history of education, one driven by the priorities of a bygone age. I personally believe they’re part of the reason we’re stuck in a curriculum developed by the Committee of Ten during the Second Industrial Age. In short, grades are part of that regimen of carrots and sticks schools use to extrinsically manage and motivate students. As you’ll read in the Kohn article, they actually have the opposite effect. But perhaps more importantly, as Daniel Pink points out in his book Drive, this approach produces the worst results when it comes to engendering the kind of deep, nuanced, complex thinking we’ll need to confront the definitional tasks of the 21st century tasks. As Pink states in his TED talk, If we really want high performance on those definitional tasks of the 21st century, the solution is not to do more of the wrong things, entice people with a sweeter carrot, or threaten them with a sharper stick. We need a whole new approach. Here’s the full talk for that if you’re interested:  I know I haven’t gotten into a lot of specifics in this admittedly short article. I hope you’ll consider checking out some more of the resources and seeing why this approach is so needed. Thanks for reading.
